title: 109_hr2865
content:
The "Keeping Families Together Act of 2005" includes provisions such as the restoration of the definition of aggravated felony, detention policy, repeal of time stop provisions, and judicial review provisions. Section 321 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is repealed, restoring the provisions of law amended by it. Aliens affected by changes in the definition of "aggravated felony" can apply for adjustment of status or cancellation of removal. Additionally, there is a restoration of detention policy. The amendment to Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act mandates the detention of aliens convicted of aggravated felonies upon release, without the possibility of release by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The amendment to Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act requires the detention of aliens convicted of aggravated felonies upon release, with no possibility of release by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The amendment also specifies conditions for the removal of aliens, including demonstrating lawful admission or inability to be removed to a designated country. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF TIME STOP PROVISIONS. Repeals Section 240A(d) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Effective date is retroactive to the enactment of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996.

SEC. 5. REPEAL OF SECTION 101(A)(48). Repeals Paragraph (48) of section 101(a)(48) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Effective date is retroactive to the enactment of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996.

SEC. 6. RESTORATION OF SECTION 212(C). The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow aliens with permanent residence to return after voluntarily going abroad for up to seven years without deportation orders. The Secretary of Homeland Security has discretion in admitting these individuals, except for those convicted of aggravated felonies with a minimum 5-year imprisonment. The Immigration and Nationality Act amendment allows permanent residents to return after voluntary travel abroad for up to seven years without deportation, with exceptions for those convicted of aggravated felonies carrying a minimum 5-year imprisonment. The effective date of the amendment is April 24, 1996. SEC. 7. RESTORATION OF JUDICIAL REVIEW PROVISIONS. Amends Section 242 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow judicial review of orders of removal. Sec. 242 of the Immigration and Nationality Act establishes the exclusive procedure for judicial review of final removal orders against aliens in the United States. Petitions for review must be filed within specific time frames, and venue is determined by the circuit where the administrative proceedings took place. The Immigration and Nationality Act establishes the procedure for judicial review of removal orders against aliens in the United States. Petitions for review must be filed within specific time frames, and venue is determined by the circuit where the administrative proceedings took place. The action is brought against the Department of Homeland Security, with service made upon the Secretary of Homeland Security and the official in charge of the district where the court is located. Service of the petition stays the removal of the alien pending court determination, unless the alien is convicted of an aggravated felony. The court may not stay the removal of an alien during the petition process unless directed otherwise. The petition will be decided based solely on the administrative record and the Secretary of Homeland Security's findings, which are conclusive if supported by substantial evidence. If a petitioner claims to be a U.S. national and the claim is not frivolous, the court must address the issues presented. The court may transfer proceedings to a district court for a de novo hearing on a petitioner's nationality claim if a genuine issue exists. Any review of an order under this section must also include a review of a motion to reopen or reconsider the order. The validity of a removal order can be challenged in a criminal proceeding by a separate motion for judicial review before trial. If a genuine issue of material fact regarding the alien's nationality is raised, a de novo hearing will be granted. The validity of a removal order can be challenged in a criminal proceeding by a separate motion for judicial review before trial. If a genuine issue of material fact regarding the alien's nationality is raised, a de novo hearing will be granted. Any alien subject to such a hearing shall not have the issue determined under section 360(a) of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security's findings of fact, supported by substantial evidence, will be conclusive if no de novo hearing on nationality is conducted. If the removal order is invalidated, the indictment will be dismissed, and the US can appeal within 30 days. The section allows any alien to file during a criminal proceeding for violation of section 243 of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security is not required to defer removal after a removal order is issued, and can detain the alien at any time. Printing the record is not necessary. The section allows any alien to obtain judicial review of a removal order through habeas corpus proceedings. An order of removal can be reviewed only after exhausting administrative remedies or if the alien has left the United States. The section allows aliens to seek judicial review of a removal order through habeas corpus proceedings. A petition for review or habeas corpus must indicate if the order's validity has been upheld in prior judicial proceedings. A petition will not be considered if the order's validity has already been determined, unless new grounds are presented or the prior remedy was inadequate. A petition challenging a final removal order can only dispute the alien's identity. The amendment limits the court's jurisdiction to review specific issues related to an alien's identity, aggravated felony convictions, and procedural requirements. It will take effect immediately and apply to pending determinations with final administrative decisions. The court cannot review any other issues beyond those specified. SEC. 8. POST-PROCEEDING RELIEF FOR AFFECTED ALIENS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a process for eligible aliens in removal proceedings to apply for cancellation of removal. Additionally, the Secretary should utilize parole authority for affected aliens. Parole authority may be used under section 212(d)(5)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act for aliens removed from the United States to participate in the established process.
